												This is one of the most gratifying things about being an older gamer: when fans of popular franchises grow up and get jobs in the video game industry. A lot of uncharitable things can be said for media culture's habit of remaking, rebooting and rehashing old stories, but when it's done from the heart like Transformers: War for Cybertron plainly is, the result is very often a damn good time. See Joss Whedon's "Avengers" or Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill" movies: both are exuberant love letters to their source material and it shows.If you have fond memories of the 1980s iteration of The Transformers[www.imdb.com] cartoon up to and including the 1986 movie[www.imdb.com], High Moon Studios' first TF outing is a high-octane shot of finely-tuned nostalgia. From the minute you start up one of the game's two single-player campaigns (one for the Decepticons, and one for the Autobots - just for story's sake, I recommend you play them in that order, although the game gives you the option to choose), you will feel like a kid again, plopped in front of the TV after school watching the Autobots smash the bolts out of some Decepticreeps. Peter Cullen voices Optimus for the umpteenth time and hits it out of the park of course, and while he is, I believe, the only voice actor present from the original series, the rest of the talent is excellent and written in exactly the same style as the old cartoons. So you get the familiar banter of Megatron/Starscream, Megatron/Soundwave (the original bromance), Soundwave/everyone, Starscream/Skywarp/Thundercracker, Optimus/Ironhide, Bumblebee/everyone, but also some not-so-familiar characters like Air Raid & Warpath, both of which are hilariously scripted and voiced and really feel like they could be right out of the show. The story is a straight prequel of the cartoon: Cybertron is a war-torn mechanical planet, the Decepticons want to grab all the power they can, the Autobots kinda don't want them to, someone gets a little too Dr. Strangelove on things and oops, we have to leave the planet because we broke it. You're not gonna get Spec Ops: The Line or Bioshock Infinite out of this -- it's robots beating the crap out of each other, innit? But it is a pitch-perfect story with a delicious topping of fanboyism and if you're the target audience even a tiny bit, you'll love it.So what about the game itself? Well... I hesitate to say too much because my inner kid loves the theme-park-ness to pieces, but it is unfortunately a rather average third-person shooter. That's not to say it's badly done, it's not. Technically it's spot-on, it looks good and plays well, but does it do anything new? Not really. It should have a cover system, it doesn't. You can transform into whatever vehicle your chosen robot is, which is awesome, but it doesn't really matter other than stretches of levels where it's either transform or run a lot (and you run slow, but okay, you weigh ten tons). The controls for vehicle mode are kind of frustrating (game devs: no one enjoys driving with a mouse. It was new and weird in Borderlands, it's old and annoying now. It really is. Stop doing it) and it's disappointing that you don't get a greater sense of speed when you're in "boost mode". The guns sound great, but they could have more variety. The world certainly looks like Cybertron, which again: awesome, however all the metal-on-metal-with-the-occasional-sky motif can be a little boring. But Cybertron is basically Coruscant with less trees, so I'm not sure what else they were supposed to do. There's not a lot in the way of exploration, either for collectibles (there are some, but they very much feel like an afterthought) or just because, and it can't be called anything but a very linear experience. But that's more or less okay since it really tries to be an extended episode of the cartoon, and in that, it succeeds. Hugely. But... all of that does sadly mean that in my opinion if you have little to no desire in watching a bunch of robots shoot each other while making snarky comments, you will probably not miss much by giving this game a pass. There are much better shooters if that's what you want.But if you are a Transformers fan at all, grab this. Grab it grab it grab it. It's fantastic, and I can't wait to play Fall of Cybertron.(Quick note on multiplayer (and a quick note is all it is since I have no experience with it): it's supposed to be good. Fall of Cybertron is supposed to be even better. That's it! There are plenty of other reviews for the multiplayer side and the consensus is, again, "good". "Fun", even. I don't know what else to tell you.)

Transformers: War for Cybertron is a 3rd Person Action Shooter. The Cybertronian Civil War takes a turn when Megatron and his Decepticons get hold of an ancient power source, just as a new Autobot leader emerges to face him.Pros: The story, although linear, is solid with great voice acting and writing, as you walk the grounds of Cybertron facilities, prisons and cities in a 10-chapter campaign that has you battling in squads of iconic characters from the series (pretty fun in co-op, too!). Each chapter will have you choose from three characters with different class, weapons and vehicle form, a selection that varies with each chapter. Transforming is an essential part of combat, as robot form allows you to jump, do special moves and carry up to two weapons, while vehicle mode allows faster movement and strafing as well as alternative weapon & ammo reserve. Graphics are pretty good, textures being higher resolution in-game than in cut scenes, while sound effects feel genuine to Transformers.Cons: Besides being able to transform, combat is nothing special, as there is no cover system beyond moving your character behind an obstacle, and weapons go from generic machine gun to generic shotgun, generic missile launcher, generic sniper, and anything in between. You might think melee combat would be an alternative, but in fact it feels worst as each melee strike takes a few seconds to complete, meaning you'll avoid using it at all in tougher fights unless the enemy AI happens to come within range. The characters, enemies, obstacles and backgrounds all have the same aesthetic and look, making it hard to know what's what in the heat of a firefight. As for the campaign length, well, let's just say they could've been longer seeing the only replay value lies with what's left of the multiplayer community.Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list!This isn't the Batman: Arkham Asylum of Transformers, but it's no doubt the best we'll get. Hasbro has certified it as an official canon prequel to the Transformers, so it's pretty awesome for a fan to see how Starscream came to join the Decepticons, how Optimus became a Prime, and what events took place in the times before the Autobots left Cybertron. While non-fans may find this game to be a plain 3rd Person Shooter, I still strongly recommend it!—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

												It's not only one of the best Transformers games out there, it's also one hell of an action game, with a unique theme, varied gameplay and lots of cool mechanics not present in other third person shooters. Though the story and execution are not as epic as the sequel - Fall of Cybertron - the overall gameplay is still thoroughly enjoyable and well paced. WfC also offers a bit better vehicle sections than FoC, and way better and more challenging boss fights. Not to mention, being able to select one of three characters available for a specific chapter is definitely a plus.People familiar with the Transformers will immediatelly appreciate the amazing animations and the artstyle faithful to Generation One, but the overall graphics are impressive on their own. One drawback I can think of in that regard is that it can be too dark/brown at times, with enemies being hard to distinguish from the rest of the environment. As for the audio, let's just say it's almost flawless, featuring some great music tracks, quite powerful sound effects, and an amazing voiceover, with numerous actors reprising their roles as familiar robots from the original show.Still, even though the PC port is very much playable, it's quite lacking in many respects. From unrebindable controls, 30fps lock, minimal graphics options, to a complete lack of DLC, and multiplayer being full of cheaters. That aside though, it's still an awesome shooter, worth playing despite these drawbacks for the story campaign alone.

												TL;DR: A wonderful game that gives Transformers justice. Very chaotic and immersive coupled with a compelling story. It's flaws are present, but not game breaking. Hail Megatron!A grand justification to the  brand. Transformers: War for Cybertron redifines the bots we know and love without straying too far from the G1 look and feel. A Bay approach to the weapons would have been worlds better.Overall, I enjoyed this game immensely and I am eager to play the second.

Short version: 83%War for Cybertron tries to be faithful to the core of the TransFormers mythos, but it also manages to tell its own story with a good amount of writing; especially considering that the game itself is just a typical squad-based third-person shooter of above average quality.Long version:The developers at High Noon obviously were no strangers to the TransFormers franchise: their game, War for Cybertron, proves this by paying homage to many of the numerous incarnations of these characters, yet still telling its own unique tale.The core concept is similar to the War Within comic series by Simon Furman: it takes place at the zenith of the civil war fought between the Autobots and Decepticons, where the tide seemingly turns as the Decepticon leader, Megatron gains new powers by taming the dark powers of energon (the lifeblood of these robots); and the only thing that can stand in his way is a newly-elected Autobot Prime, Optimus, and his faithful soldiers.This story is presented in a co-op third-person shooter format, which in single-player translates to the player controlling one of the three robots and gaining two computer-controlled allies. These allies are immortal, but their contribution mostly stops at being additional targets. Still, this helps in many situations, sometimes leading to a surprising level of strategy. And to make things better, the trios talk a lot, so there is never a dull moment during the levels. I cannot say gameplay is perfect though. Not counting technical issues like locked frame rate or unchangeable controls, there are design problems like a lack of ammunition, rendering many weapons with small magazines virtually useless. Some parts also feel untested and incredibly unfair, the final boss fights being the most notorious.With the constant presence of these issues, I can only recommend this otherwise good game for those who are in no shortage of patience—especially if they like to play on higher difficulties.

												'Transformers: War for Cybertron' was designed for 'Transformers' fans, especially those who grew up watching the first generation of 'Transformers' (G1) cartoons and playing with the toys. While the aesthetics of the Transformers in the game were partly inspired by the robots in Michael Bay's movies, the robots thankfully looked much more like the G1 Transformers for the most part.'War for Cybertron' is a serviceable third-person action game. If it were not for the transforming robots, the game will not be as enjoyable. The developers did an excellent job in designing Cybertron. The environments were rendered and textured in great detail, and really provided an immersive gamespace. This was particularly evident in the second chapter of the game, which was one of my favourites.Perhaps it is because I grew up watching the colourful G1 cartoons, but I find it unfortunate that the game's colour palette was predominantly shades of grey, red, purple and brown. Most parts of 'War for Cybertron' were so dark that, if it were not for the glowing stripes on the robots (à la 'Tron'), I would have had an even harder time seeing the enemy. While the playable Decepticons were similarly chromatically muted, the playable Autobots were thankfully more colourful and had more distinctive robot and vehicle designs. The game is divided into two parts, with the first featuring Decepticons as playable characters, and the second Autobots. Maybe because I am partial to Autobots, but I find the second half much more enjoyable. The game is mainly travelling from arena to arena, clearing each arena of enemies, and repeating this multiple times until you reach a boss battle. This got boring by Chapters 3 or 4, but the Autobot-centric chapters thankfully offered some variations to the formula. The better action setpieces and pacing of the Autobot chapters culminated in a spectacular conclusion.Despite the mediocrity of 'War for Cybertron', I will give it my lukewarm recommendation because of the game's strong second half. If you're not a big 'Transformers' fan, you can skip this game. It is worth a try -- especially the second chapter and the Autobot chapters -- if you can buy it at discount like I did. Otherwise, you may be better off playing 'Transformers: Fall of Cybertron' and 'Transformers: Devestation', both of which I heard are much better 'Transformers' games.

												This is what a Transformers movie could be like if we can somehow rescue the IP from the clutches of Michael Bay. And you even get to play a few scenes in it!Ok, snideness aside, what you have here is a decent, solid 3rd person shooter, a bit shallow on the tactical side but then again, rather stingy with the ammo for a pure relaxing glue-the-mouse-button-down zero-skill bang fest. The difficulty settings are sensible, easy does mean "you can let your 5 year old kid who is a huge Transformers fan play it and he'll make it", while hard does indeed cause a lot of headaches. Mostly 'cause the controls don't really allow a lot of tactical maneuvering and damage avoidance.That's maybe also my biggest problem with the game. There isn't really much "skill" involved.  And the basic material was really offering a lot of options in this area. There could be some moves where you could transform from robot to vehicle and back for some sweet actions, you could probably, I don't know, climb on walls, run down the wall, transform in mid air, kick up the speed, go over a ramp, transform in mid air again and grasp on a ledge ... That WOULD be awesome.Not going to happen, though. Transforming is a rather tedious and static process, don't expect to use that as part of a tactical move. You can drive, which is fast but limited in maneuverability, or you can walk as a robot, which gives you more precision over your movements but makes you slower. So what's left is a decent 3rd person shooter. Nothing great, nothing fancy, but certainly something everyone who grew up with Transformers will want to play. The story is quite predictable (so it fits perfectly with the old Transformers cartoons) but very well told, the voice acting is, well, not great but most of the time at least decent (again, fits perfectly with the old cartoons), with the usual overacting of the minor characters (again, like the cartoons). The only thing missing is the cheesy intro.

												I love this game. I played it on the PS3 first, maxed everything out and started playing escalation regularly. My friends and I launched ourselves to the top of the escalation leaderboards, becoming frustrated at the bugs plaguing the PS3 version that prevented you from playing escalation indefinitely. When you made it so far in the PS3 version of escalation, the game would for some reason begin to glitch and freeze after some time, causing you to lose all your points. Eventually, we decided we would glitch through the walls and jump off the map to kill ourselves at wave 50 so we didn't lose all our points when we inevitably froze. Then the PS3 network got hacked, and I went out and bought a 360 (after the network was down for two weeks) literally JUST to play this game. I of course got the Halo games and Skyrim and other fun games for 360, but I mostly played WFC. Then I got my new job and games had much less time in my life, but this one always held a place in my heart. Eventually I made the jump to a PC and built my first rig, buying this game as soon as I downloaded Steam. This game is the best. I love how they captured the feel of Cybertron and the feel of G1. The drop-in drop-out co-op is an excellent system to play through the campaign with your friends. Though I will say that a big flaw of that system is the limited availability of the weapons and ammo for all three players. Even more annoying is when a noob joins and dies constantly and causes you to keep replaying the same part of that mission until they either leave or somehow make it through.Multiplayer, while fun, is dead. Even when it's not dead, hackers are a constant annoyance. They are the worst.I mostly focus on escalation now, as I did before. The online community for this game is very limited, as there are few people who want to play a nearly six year old Transfomers game that was a "meh" port at best. Online communications are non existent. In game, you are required to make a new account to play. You don't need to register an Email address or anything, just type a name in and if it's not taken then it's yours. You add friends you meet online by typing in their names and waiting for them to accept your request. There is no voice chat, there is no text chat. The port to PC was lazily and hastily done and the online experience suffers as a result. The framerate is also capped at 30FPS for no damn reason. Thankfully, Googling "Transformers: War for Cybertron frame unlocker" will lead you to a third-party free-to-use tool that can unlock it for you. And they also chose to not allow DLC for this game which is crap. You can unlock the characters through googling "Transformers: War for Cybertron coalesced.ini" which will lead you to a guide and a new ini file which fixes a few things and allows you to play as the DLC characters, but doesn't give you the maps. The new maps were awesome, and I think that PC players are seriously missing out on those maps because High Moon was too damn lazy to make a proper PC port. After you download those two things though, the game is much more enjoyable.All in all, it's a great, amazing Transformers experience. I love it. I've always loved it, and will play it for as long as it continues to be supported. But user beware, there is very little of the online community that once populated this game left. If you have a PS3 or 360, I would recommend playing it on either of those platforms instead, but the 360 will be more enjoyable. And you'll be able to get a used copy for the consoles much cheaper I'm sure. Still, if you must play it on PC, it's still a blast. Despite my griping, I would highly recommend this game to anyone with a soft spot for Transformers, or who enjoys a well built, fun to play, fast paced shooter.

The multiplayer is outstanding and after many hours still great to play. You can choose your weapons and abilities and then use them in multiplayer. The maps are all very different, most are medium size to big which will allow for different play styles for all different players. 												Note: This review is for the solo campaign mode only.Note 2: The game is locked at 30 fps by default. You can download an uncapper (see the game's PCGamingWiki entry) that will allow you to unlock the frame rate with no negative gameplay effects. With the uncapper, I was able to get 60 fps most of the time on my i5-3470/GTX 970 system. There were still sporadic moments where it would dip back into the 30s for a few seconds, though this happened even on minimum settings, so I have to assume this was just the result of some flaw that the uncapper couldn't fix rather than my hardware. These were rare enough to not negatively affect my enjoyment of the game.Gameplay review: This game is actually the first Transformers story I've ever experienced in any medium and I enjoyed the story more than I was expecting. I think a lot of that has to do with the great voice acting.The gameplay is generic, but satisfying, third-person shooting that succeeds because of the sheer amount of spectacle. It's quite linear but the strong pacing kept me interested regardless.The game is split into two five-mission campaigns: the initial Decepticon campaign, which features Megatron doing generic evil genius stuff, and the Autobot campaign, in which Optimus attempts to foil Megatron's plans.While the gameplay between the two campaigns is mostly the same, the Autobot campaign is much harder than the Decepticon campaign. I played on hard, and despite the campaigns having the same number of levels, it took me 4 hours to beat the Decepticon campaign and 10 hours to beat the Autobot campaign. Even on hard, the Decepticon campaign is staggeringly easy, but the degree of difficulty ramps up massively in the second mission of the Autobot campaign and remains that way until the end of the game. The main reason for this is a difference in the design of the combat spaces between the two campaigns: Levels in the Decepticon campaign tend to feature lots of linear corridors and small rooms with plenty of cover, which means you can stand behind cover and blast enemies to your heart's content. Rooms also usually only feature 3-5 enemies at most. However, in the Autobot campaign, you're frequently placed into large arena-like spaces with very limited cover, limited health pick-ups, and overwhelming numbers of spongey enemies. Dodging and pinpoint accuracy become essential for survival. The degree with which the difficulty increases almost made me give up, but I stuck it out until the end I guess through stubbornness?If you don't like being frustrated by your games, you might want to play this one on medium. If you like a real challenge, play on hard, and you'll find what you're looking for once you get through the first five easy levels.

												Buy? Maybe.-=TL;DR=-It's a solid, but standard non-cover based third person shooter that's  respectful to the Transformer universe and not related to the Michael Bay films. The campaign is generally well-paced (though, levels were a tad longer than I wanted) and provided a mostly fufilling insight into the backstory of the Transformers. Multiplayer is dead (0 players in any playlist), though co-op has about 30-70 regularl players as of June 2014, though I find it inferior to other popular co-op horde shooters. WFC is a no brainer for Transformers fans, and a good buy at a sale for others. It's clearly a console port with no rebindable keys, no achievements, no form of multiplayer chat (on a PC shooter? Are you kidding me?) and a 29 FPS cap (fixable with a 3rd party software)-=Presentation=-WFC looks last gen: many textures are blurry, especially on boss type enemies, polygon edges are clearly visible on round objects , and plays at a capped 29FPS. The game isn't ugly (except for close ups on some textures) and looks great for it's time. I love cyber/techpunk environments, so I enjoy the sci-fi look of the game. While the world does suffers from typical shooter browngrey syndrome, theres' many splashes of color thanks to lighting effects of objects and certain background features as well as the robots themselves.Transformers fans will like that this has no relation to the Michael Bay films. While still 90% action and explosions, you're not dealing with humans and none of the immature humor  is here. Thankfully, comedy mostly come from interactions with specific characters, but without the corniness of the orignal toon. WFC, in my opinion, provides a great insight into the Transformers origins, as somebody who has only seen limited viewings of the original and Armada cartoons as well as the Bay films. You get a better sense of why the robots are fighting, instead of "those bots are purple and bad and must be defeated by the nice, red robots" and the amount of destruction and "death" of Transformer-kind gives you context into why the war is such a big deal to them. That said, the Decepticon side seems a bit stupid if they want to complete their goal, as Megatron's philosophy boils down to "destroy everything and kill those who are weak". You don't get the ability to revive non-essential NPCs until the Autobot campaign - Megatron doesn't want to help his fellow army, but ♥♥♥♥♥es if he isn't healed. Thankfully, he isn't as stupid as he was in the show, as he wants to kill Starscream who clearly intends on betraying him, but simply doesn't have the time or the ability to thanks to the war and their locations at the time.It's absolutely fantastic that they have the original Optimus Prime voice actor who is among my all time favorite voices. I don't know if any other character voices are from the original show, but most of the main characters are fit perfectly. The soundtrack isn't must-have, but there are some nice epic/rock themes and the original 80's hair metal theme in the credits is delightful to hear. The majority of the music fits the setting well.-=Gameplay=-Gameplay here is uninteresting besides transforming. This provides faster movement and a 3rd or 4th weapon depending on the bot. In some cases, the transformation for some bots is a little OP as you might be able to constantly hover, dodge and shoot with unlimited ammo, compared to the limited ammo of ground weapons which can easily be drained if you're not accurate and using melee and abiliites.  Vehicle mode is either used to travel a long distance or to escape. Thankfully, controlling the vehicle is fairly easy - it makes me wonder why there isn't some "Transformers Arena" car combat/racing game spinoff based off this mechanic. Oddly enough, vehicle mode feels very slow compared to driving a car in most games, and is really more of a sprint for these guys. Considering their size, it probably would look faster compared to a human, but looks slow in the context of Transformers.There's no cover system, so survival is mostly about killing the enemy first and hiding. As I said before, ammo is a problem in bot mode, so you must be accurate and use melee often. All bots have two abilities, one goverened by a cooldown and the other by energon pickups from killed enemies. I rarely used them due to their limited use and usually, it was better to stay at range and shoot, instead of using abilities, with a few exceptions. Occasionally, you will also have grenades. Also, it never pays to be a healer player in the campaign, your two sidekicks never die and if you're the healing player, then the other teammates won't be able to heal you. Like most shooters, the majority of enemies go down faster than you, though you can get killed pretty easily if you're not careful. It's inconsistent as you watch scenes of bots fighting head to head while you must run cover to cover to fight against groups. You wlll also do 98% of the combat work and 100% of the "Press E to interact" work (except for when team mates use turrets), but thankfully, your teammates are half-decent at attracing some fire from you and killing a few enemies here and there.I did like that the final battle was against an albiet cliche, giant, big bad robot. But the battle itself was cheesy and annoying - the boss can kill you relatively easily with missles that almost never miss (and honestly, he should be able to just grab and crush or smash the Autobots with ease), yet, you can hide yourself in an alcove on the left side of the map and take no damage. It's very stupid to go from, "How the hell do I survive these impossible rockets" to "Let's huddle here in this spot indefinitely while the boss shoots at the cover with futility". The overall battle was a pretty lame "shoot explosive containers" and then "hit the weakpoint for massive damage" trope.Don't buy this for Multiplayer - even with 69 players online, nobody was playing it. The Co-op is where most of these people are at. At it's core, it's a fairly decent "kill waves of enemies you fought in campaign" while earning points. However, the point system is massively flawed - if you join a room late in the game, you will  run out of ammo shooting enemies that require tons of damage and can kill you fast. And since the ONLY way to get points is to kill enemies (that's right, no points for assists or anything else), you won't be able to buy weapons, help team mates open doors, restock ammo or even just restore health. While sharing points to open doors or purchase items is neat, it's absolutely incompetent that you can get stuck with no chance of redemption unless you start in an early round or get the last hit like a MOBA. Some of you can probably put up with it if you have a decent team and you START AT THE FIRST WAVE, but the Co-op from Mass Effect 3 and Warframe are better in every aspect.-=Conclusion=-WFC does justice to the Transformer universe, and I'm looking forward to Fall of Cybertron since I've heard good reviews. The gameplay is solid, though, largely unremarkable except for the transformer mechanic, in which honestly, I didn't use often, except for when I could abuse unlimited ammo. The overall presentation is pretty good and in some cases awesome. It can be beat in about 10-12 hours and I recommend medium difficulty - even though I can play well on hard, it made some sections irritating and I just want to clear my backlog. $20 would generally be a fair price, but in the era of PC game discounts and bundles, Activision should sell this no more than $15. Wait for a sale where it's often less than $10.

												Transformers War For Cybertron is a love letter to the 1980's era Transformers and if you're a fan of the series young or old you'll probably find something to love about Transformers Fall of Cybertron, and have enough fond feelings to overlook some of the problems this PC port has.The game play is third person action shooter that has you running gunning and transforming. Most sections are designed for robot combat and you'll strafe around shooting at the opposition but a few areas are designed for mobility in mind where transforming into your vehicle mode is required. These segments are well done and the transition from robot to vehicle feels as good as you'd expect it should. The shooting segments can get repetitive and with out a cover option you'll find yourself mostly strafing back and forth to avoid fire which feels a bit clunky. You'll often find your friendly AI companions getting in the way and they 're really only there for you to have a choice of one of three characters to choose from at the beginning of each mission and for bantering back and forth. There was never a time I felt like they did any thing to help me, and a few times where they got in the way. Multilayer is a lot more fun then I expected. You level up your class, customize skills based off your play style. Its actually pretty diverse and fun. The game can be visually cluttered at times, as a living robotic planet with lots of moving parts is important to the setting but can get sort of messy on screen when laser battles are breaking out and you're shifting in between robot and vehicle forms but it's a minor complaint. If you play with a controller it's a bit annoying that it's only partially supported, so get used to memorizing buttons as every in-game prompt you see will be keyboard & mouse specific. I never ran into any major problems because of this but it was annoying. All and all a fun time to be had, especially if you're a fan of the series. And it's got a Stan Bush song... What else can I say?

												TL;DR - Yes, the shooting mechanics themselves are somewhat clunky, but it's still an effing TRANSFORMERS THIRD-PERSON SHOOTER, and it works!Of all the things in the gaming world, I would have never expected the successful fusion of the Transformers brand and a third-person shooter, yet, here we are. Somebody more articulate than I once said that “War for Cybertron” and its sequels were essentially the equivalent of the Batman Arkham games; both reinvent these franchises in the gaming world with gameplay systems that prove surprisingly effective in supporting the setting and characters. Granted, my (albeit limited) knowledge of Transformers doesn’t really include mowing down waves upon waves of nameless Cybertronians using one of three varieties of machine gun, but the core aesthetic of teamed-up, tough-talking transforming space robots is still present and strong. The shooting mechanics themselves are thankfully varied; in addition to the existence of a sizable arsenal, the ability to transform into a vehicle and grant yourself a completely different loadout (with its own reserve of ammo) ensures that you never really stop “going” through a level. A lot of the luster in the weaponry lies in the flashy pyrotechnics they produce; it may be an Unreal Engine 3 game, but it still is quite a looker by today’s standards. The game’s excellent pacing exists also in thanks to variability in level design; sure, the concept of the “action setpiece” is an often lambasted one, but the frequency at which War for Cybertron throws different ones at you is something to be admired, at least. That said, War for Cybertron is by no means a “Gears of War”-quality TPS; for all of the aftermentioned flashiness and particle effects, there lacks a certain gravity in how weapons effect enemies.  In other words: “bulletsponge” enemies, and a lot of them at that, especially in the late game. Also, the lack of a “hold to aim/zoom” toggle is annoying, but not as sizable a problem as the game’s biggest sin of incomplete controller support. Yes, the game is technically playable using a 360 controller, but good luck finding documentation of any kind on what actions the buttons are assigned to. I’ve also heard that certain vehicle sections are not mapped correctly, making the prospect of successfully using a controller unlikely, to say the least. Final words: In the end however, I think Transformers: War for Cybertron is definitely worth a play, because when all is said and done, it’s still a totally competent shooter. By itself, that’s not much of a feat, but when attached to the Transformers brand, of all properties, it totally freaking is.

												Decent, good looking game.  It's fairly short and I can't see it having a ton of replay value but for fans of the series or the comics it's got a lot to like.  It has a lot to gripe about for your really committed fans both in terms of story and game mechanics but it still beats the pants off anything Michael Bay is going to shovel out.  And it still manages to blow up real good too.The voice acting is a high point and that's important--the only moderately disappointing spot here was the voice of Warpath sounded more like he was doing Hot Rod with a few "whams" and "booms" sprinkled into his speech.  The character models are all faithful to the Generation 1-leaning Cybertronian look of some of the newer toys and comics as well.  I know I said it was short but I can see the gameplay getting repetitive if it went on for a whole lot longer.  The transformation mechanic melds well with the overall feel of the gameplay and is fairly smooth and seamless.  While the weapons are a bit iffy, you'll figure out quickly which ones you want and which ones you pick up only if you have no other option.  It's unfortunate that there wasn't a bit more distinction in the guns, especially in the sense that both Megatron and Optimus Prime's weapons don't work much differently from the garden-variety peashooters you will usually leave behind.  Really, if there's one problem with this game it's that every character and every gun feels pretty much the same.  The only real difference in how they play is whether the character turns into a ground vehicle or a jet of some kind.  Of course, if you're enough of a fan to still be reading this, then the similarity really doesn't matter.

												Being a staunch fan of the original series, I had longed for a Transformers game that did justice to the original material and characters, and War for Cybertron mostly does the series proud.  There are several interesting things about the game.  First of all, it's basically a prequel to the series, which helps to explain how the Cybertronian wars started.  Secondly, you play half the game as the Decepticons, and the other half as the Autobots.  The characters are all animated well, you can transform as often as you want, and there is a wide range of favorite characters to choose from, including  Megatron and Soundwave on the Decepticon side, and Optimus Prime, Ironhide, and Ratchet on the Autobot side.  An interesting array of weapons, a real sense of outer space and Cybertron, and great boss battles with giants Omega Supreme and Trypticon help round it out, though there could be more variety in the minor enemies. Still, War for Cybertron is definitely the Transformers game to get.

This review is based on about the hour or so of gameplay I played during a $5 sale before returning the product. As such I am limited to what I experienced. Please keep this in mind!War for Cybertron was a game that I heard a lot of good things about. With it being Transformers (a series that I enjoyed quite a bit in my childhood, although not quite on the same level as my brother) I was excited to give it a try. What I got was less than desirable. While I initially was reluctant to review a product that I had such little time with, I felt it was important to share my feelings about the game to give others a better sense of what they should expect / recieve.The gameplay in this game is rather interesting. The fact that you can transform SEEMS like it would offer quite a bit of variation on combat. That's not quite true. Transforming merely seemed like another gun and a slightly altered means of transportation with flying, which is actually useful, and driving, which switches between sluggish or super sonic speed depending on your actions. This just feels clumsy and really serves more as a gimmick.Jumping is odd. You have a double jump, but most obstacles feel like you need to use both anyway. Not solid, but I can't say it was terrible.Camera controls. Ugh, I'm not a fan of them. Having an over the shoulder perspective is usually a hit or miss due to the fact that they often pick a side to stick with. This is USUALLY a bad design decision unless levels are built around that. This is a game that does that and isn't built for it. (At least as far as I could find control wise, correct me if I'm wrong.) Imagine hiding behind cover with a camera stuck on your right shoulder and an enemy attacking you. Due to the fact that he resides on the left side of the screen you are unable to attack him without coming out of cover.Which leads to my next complaint. Cover is pretty much nonexistent. Sure you can stand behind things, but this feels incredibly inadequate and often leads to the damage you take feeling cheap. With a small health bar and only medkits to replenish health, it seems odd that avoiding damage is so tricky. (While I might have been bad at this game and thus affecting my view on this, I will say that I don't always suck.)Ammo feels lacking. With most enemies taking at least half a magazine of bullets to finish off unless using a weapon with more sparse ammo (and thus being more deadly.) This means that the rigid car mode is something you'll find yourself stuck using to alleviate this problem.Making an account for Co-op and online play is actually incredibly easy and gets major applause for it. All it asks is for a name and your pretty much good to go. No hassle and I was done in ten seconds flat. (Although adding a friend seems to be a mutual process.)However the actual Co-op feels slapped on. Ammo and health had the biggest impact on this situation. The levels are designed to give enough for one player. When you add another robot providing support but using the same resources you start having someone (or even multiple) people in the party having to stay behind because they are out of something crucial. This could have easily been fixed by having the health and ammo work for both players, or just dropping duplicates of them.Not only that but you'll find that if your partner runs just a little bit ahead, most doors end up closing on the other(s) before they can make it through. Their solution is to simply toss the player left behind into the next room. This is very disorienting and really isn't a good solution. Still it does get the job done.The enviroment is definitely done well and really feels "robotic" and futuristic. The problem I have with it though is that enemies are too easily hidden and indistinguishable from the background. This might have just been a problem for me.The story is something I truly can't speak on. As I said at the start of this, I only had about an hour or so to experience it. What I did experience though in the story was lackluster. The only thing I remember was Megatron being an absolute meanace and everyone else basically saying, DARK ENERGON IS DANGEROUS! It hit me over the head again and again, and was simply too straight foward for me to care about. Now Transformers is based on a pretty young demographic and isn't really known for deep and complex story. Still, I would have wagered that a more "mature" artstyle would mean trusting the player a little bit more on following the story.Unfortunately I didn't get to try my hand on the multiplayer. I suppose it's possible that a lot of the fun to be had here is in this mode, but we are also talking about a game that's quite a few years old. While you might be able to round some people up, servers are going to be lacking a strong player base.The game just feels lacking, and while some fanatics of Transformers might really enjoy this game, it just doesn't stand on its own AS a game. Still, others clearly seem to have found some fun playing it. At $5 on sale most people won't care about these problems or might find it more enjoyable than I did. For me, it just wasn't enough. Overall I rate the game about a 4/10. A below average game for me that I sadly can not recommend.

Posted: August 27, 2015
												Imagine that a cable science-fiction channel had an unexpected gap to fill in its programming and for contractual reasons with its advertisers the content had to be something new rather than a re-run. They tell their youngest unpaid interns about this at 5 o'clock as they're packing up to leave, saying it had better be ready to air by the next morning. Already exhausted from a mid-week birthday party that lasted well into the previous night, and having never done anything like this before, the interns must write, direct, act, and produce their own made-for-TV-movie in just a few hours.That's exactly how Transformers: War for Cybertron must've been created.The graphics and gameplay are just Unreal Tournament skinned with a few tweaks. Inaccurate, unpowerful weapons. Dull, blurry textures. Locked in third-person mode. Extremely slow movement speed even when things are supposed to be rushed. Collecting glowing shards from defeated enemies that do absolutely nothing. All the changes make things worse, and UT did not have a strong single player campaign to begin with.The dialogue and voice acting are so bad as to be laughable if only the game didn't take itself so seriously. The story and some of its moments just shatter any suspension of disbelief. This is a problem with Transformers in general (why in the world would a group of alien machines transform into exact replicas of vehicles meant to transport humans when they've never seen any before (this is a prequel after all)? Or for that matter, why do they even have two arms, two legs, and faces? Those things are utterly irrelevant to a machine's existence) but this game exacerbates them. Oh there's a hard terminal to hack? The solution is to reduce the power being sent to it. Because a computer's incoming power affects its security. Idiotic doesn't even begin to describe it.The one saving grace is the boss fights. Some of them are a fun diversion for a few moments. And they're consistently the only parts of the game that can't be ignored and just sprinted through. But they are the vast minority of where your time will be spent during a play through.I bought this game to play co-op, but it's honestly one of the only games where I can't imagine co-op making it better. Maybe you'd be able to make fun of it with your partner in real time. What a silver lining that would be.

												A great idea, and stunningly well designed, thought out game. The graphics are fantastic, the sound and voice acting a actually pretty surprisingly good... all around, it's a great game.But...The game is so agonizingly linear that it tends to ruin the rest of it. The custom characters are also ONLY available if you play multiplayer against other people, which is also the only way to level up and unlock new equipment and abilities (of which there tend to be may 2 at best for any given character type).despite actually liking the game, it is so basic and bland that I couldn't stomach putting in the effort to finish it. I'll use the hard drive space for a game that doesnt drag me along by the wrist.

												Personal Rating: 4 of 10If you enjoy a linear 3rd Person Shooter, this game might be the one for you. Overall the graphics, sound, voice acting, guns selection, controls, A.I. and story are alright. There are little things in the game that might surprise you. However going into the second chapter of the mission you already seen everything the game has to offer even the story. Don't expect any plots because they are predictable and minimal.You get to choose 1 out of 3 bots to play each chapter while the other two will keep you company. They are not entirely useless since they can distract and kill enemies. The environment are well designed and gives you a good feeling of the bots' home planet but maps are linear. You move from one area to another fighting swarms of bots. Clearing them will allow you to loot and restock your health and ammo. Rinse and repeat.Bots have melee attack which looks cool but practically useless since you will take loads of damage charging into combat. Each bots have unique skills but in my opinion it should be a standard issue across all bots such as dashing, hovering and etc. They also have unique weapons but nothing that really stands out from what you can picked up during your play. You cannot modify weapons or enhance it. Whats worse is you can only hold 2 weapons schematic at a time. Why schematic? Because instead of wielding the weapon, your arm transform into the weapon which is pretty cool. Most weapons uses the same ammo/energy cell so it really not necessary to limit weapons. Also, certain bots has unique weapons that can heal teammate. This is cool if your A.I. teammate can actually take damage. You cannot drop certain primary weapon so you end up only holding a single useful offensive weapon.Weapons feels solid when firing with the effects and all but falls short when hitting the enemies because no matter how much impact you feel it should hit, the enemies does not dismember and the laws of physics does not really apply here. Most of the time they simply fell to the ground.Conversation between bots can be hilarious but gets old really fast as they keep on repeating them from time to time. The second mission was the coolest in my opinion since you get to fly. But to my dismay you only get to play it once out of 6 chapters from the Decepticons and to my assumption will be similar with the Autobots. Also the map is pretty enclosed so no open space battle which is a waste.The final boss fight from the Decepticon is designed like the old school games which is challenging and some skills with quick reaction is required. But the logic behind it is hilariously insulting.This game has great potential and it tapped in correctly it can be great fun. I never completed the game because moving on to the Autobots campaign, everything seems to be the same.

												From a purely game mechanic perspective, this really isn't anything special; it's arguably sub-par. Unlike Binary Domain or Spec Ops, the title doesn't hold a compelling storyline that excuses the mediocre game mechanics. Hell, those titles at least had some differences in game mechanics that distanced them from typical titles of their respective genres. WFC gives you the ability to transform into vehicles, which really doesn't amount to anything more than a quicker way to traverse the landscape and a third in-game weapon. They really missed an opportunity here; it was somewhat explored in a few segments where you could drive through the landscape as it was engulfed in war, but otherwise it's really the biggest let-down of the game.So why am I recommending this; am I a Transformers fan? Nah, I've never watched it and have stayed away from the recent movies. I came into this a Transformers virgin (har har har). I guess this TRANSFORMED me into a, you know, non-virgin or something (HAHAHAHAHAHAH)I'm recommending this for the same reason I recommended Spec Ops and Binary Domain: interesting storyline. The story on this number is nowhere near the levels that BD and SO touched upon, but just because a plotline isn't ''deep'' doesn't mean it isn't interesting. WFC feels episodic; each chapter is introduced with a ''last time on Dragon Ball Z'' type of summary, and it all feels like a season of the show, like you're watching a cartoon and want to tune in to the next episode. Having no prior knowledge of the series, I feel that it does a good job of introducing newbies to the franchise and doesn't overwhelm you with the franchise's giant mythos. They also did this cool thing whereby you first play as the evil side before switching to the good in the aftermath of evil's victory. It's a really nice touch. The plotline is still simplistic, but the feel I got from it gave me a cozy saturday morning vibe that I thoroughly enjoyed. I didn't play it so much for the game mechanics, but to see how the Decepticons would strike back, or how the autobots would regroup.Perhaps I'm a sucker for storylines because I feel like I should stop recommending titles just on that alone. But just as before I'll use the same logic: nothing is inherently flawed with the game mechanics, and the plot is what keeps you reeled in. The game is somewhat easy; I played on hard mode in co-op (two players, there's an option for three) and it was still a breeze, save for a few battles here and there. There's a multiplayer mode, but everyime I boot up the title and go online to host a game for me and the broski the in-game menu tells me that there are around 40 players online, so it's dead. This game recommendation hinges on you enjoying a simplistic plotline that plays out like a saturday morning cartoon, or perhaps if you're into the series. Cause it does the series justice (according to a different review, at least) and when it comes to cash cow franchises you really can't expect a decent video game, but here it is. If I were to place a numerical score on this, I'd saaaayyy....6/10; it's alright, but pretty fun in co-op (like all games, really). That's what probably made this really anjoyable for me, but objectively I'd give it a 6.

												It's hard to make a good licensed game. But War for Cybertron is one of the rare examples of such: An amazingly fun third-person shooter/vehicular combat hybrid that is enriched by it's setting rather then hindered by it. Setting the game on Cybertron itself, millions of years before the Transformers took their war to Earth, was a stroke of genius (as was setting the Decepticon campaign before the Autobot one: villains act, heroes react)- there are no annoying kid sidekicks or shallow love interests here. This is pure metal action, with an impressive array of iconic characters and weapons, reimagined in their native Cybertronian forms. War for Cybertron does an amazing job of portraying the brutality of the Cybertronian wars, and making the planet and it's inhabitants feel truly alive- constantly shifting parts and glowing energy lines pervade the art style. Make of the Michael Bay films what you will- in my mind, THIS is Transformers for a new age.

												The Good: Excellent story, brings back the golden days, solid shooting, diverse weapons, looks greatThe Bad: Repetitive after awhile, abilities and transforming are practically useless, unbalanced difficulty, so-so multiplayerTransformers has always been one of those licenses that has struggled in the gaming world that produced mediocre to abysmal products that were quickly forgotten. The fine men and women at High Moon Studios have finally delivered the first excellent Transformers game that brings us back to the beloved cartoons we grew to and embrace in our hearts.You play both the Decepticon and Autobot campaigns, but you start out as the Decepticons trying to use Dark Energon to hijack the core of Cybertron and destroying the Autobots in the process. When you start each chapter you can choose one of three Transformers to play as and in the Decepticon campaign (minus the Star Scream mission) you can play as either Megatron (yes!), Soundwave, or Breakdown. Each one has unique abilities and starts out with their own weapons. Once you jump into the game controls play out like a standard third person shooter, but the game does a bit more for us here.You can carry two weapons at all times and of course you have to reload and acquire more ammo, but some times you'll find a really big weapon that you can carry, but switching to other weapons will drop it. You can use your abilities such as sucking life from enemies, or hovering, but as you can see the abilities are pretty lackluster and you never really use them ever! To regenerate your abilities you must collect fallen Energon from dead enemies. You can also transform into your vehicle form, but once again you never really have to do this unless your traveling long distances or your almost forced to. The transformations are seamless, but there's just no reason to really do it since your firearms are sufficient enough.You can throw grenades as well and one such grenade called the healing grenade is excellent since it creates a healing bubble that comes in handy a lot. The weapons are pretty versatile and very useful and High Moon did a good job giving a nice selection and you really have to decide what's the best weapon for the situation, especially during boss fights.While the game play is solid it needs to be more cinematic. The game is very straight forward and just same throughout. It's just kill wave after wave after wave then kill this boss. Each chapter replays the same formula, but offers just enough diversity to keep you playing. I wanted the game to be more cinematic and varied in game play, but maybe next time around. The game looks very good, but some of the textures are on the low resolution side, and it could have also looked so much better. However, the art style is spot on and really makes you feel like your fighting this massive war on Cybertron. The voice acting is top notch and everyone sounds alike, or almost like, their cartoon counterparts personalities and all. I do have to point out that the AI is pretty solid and gives you a good challenge, but the difficulty is poorly balanced due to easy sections then a sudden section that you die in 10 times.The multiplayer side is fun with the escalation mode that pits you against wave after wave of enemies, but the competitive side is pretty standard and not very exciting after awhile. With a compelling story, and solid enough game play and variety to keep any Transformer fan, or newcomers alike, busy but you won't have a reason to come back to play through Cybertron again unless you just want to hear your favorite metal men talk.~Score: 8/10
